Dear Melynda Elizabeth Williams:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result in
compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately please contact the area manager, Rorie Dodge-Pifer at (517) 899-6024.

Rule Code Program statement
Title

Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4109
Section (1) An institution shall have and follow a current written program
Description statement which specifically addresses all of the following: (c)
Policies and procedures pertaining to admission, care, safety, and
supervision, methods for addressing residents' needs,
implementation of treatment plans, and discharge of residents.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Allegation 1:
For the past 3 months, a staff member has been sexually
harassing a youth by making comments that make the youth
uncomfortable. When youth told management, the staff member
was transferred to another unit but has continued to return to the
unit and continues to make comments.
Allegation 2:
Agency staff purchased fast food for youth placed at the facility
and transported the youth to McDonalds without prior agency
permission.
Investigation Interviews: (Allegation 1)
On 10/25/2024 attempt was made to join interview of Youth A
being conducted by DHHS specialist via telephone without
success as connection was not stable.
On 10/30/2024 a telephone conversation was held with DHHS
Specialist. She advised that during her 10/25/2024 interview with
the Compliance Supervisor it was reported that an internal
investigation was completed by the agency and there was not
sufficient evidence found to support inappropriate behavior or
actions by Staff 1. Compliance Supervisor also advised that Youth
A had been overheard making statements about her ability to “get
staff fired”. DHHS specialist also advised about the interview with
Youth A. Youth A reported that she does not like that Staff 1
makes her feel uncomfortable. She provided specific examples
including one time she reported that Staff 1 asked her if she ever
had a “Charlie Horse” between her thighs and she responded no.
Staff 1 then followed up and asked if she wanted one. Youth A
denied Staff 1 did or said anything further. She stated he was
laughing and saying he was playing with her, but indicated she felt
he should not be playing with her like that. Youth A reported on
another instance that Staff 1 shared with the youth that he did
porn and another instance when she heard him tell another male
youth that he “needs butt”. DHHS specialist advised that Youth A
2

reported feeling “a little” safe at the facility and denied that Staff 1
had been working on her unit or interacting with her since the
safety plan had been implemented.
On 10/30/24 an in-person interview was held with Compliance
Supervisor at Whaley. She advised that Staff 1 is currently on
medical leave. The HR history of Staff 1 was discussed. She
further advised that no other youth or staff have made reports
regarding Staff 1.
On 10/30/24 an in-person interview was held with Youth A at
Whaley’s. Youth A confirmed that she has been at the facility for
6 months. When asked about encounters she has had with Staff
1, she responded that she did not want to talk about it and that
she has been trying to get it off her mind. She initially refused to
answer any questions, but later agreed to answer a couple of
questions. Youth A denied that she had been asked if she ever
had a Charlie horse between her legs by a staff at Whaley and
she also denied that she has seen Staff 1 again in her unit at
Whaley’s.
On 10/30/24 a voicemail message was left for Complainant
requesting a return call with any additional information.
On 10/30/24 a voicemail message was left for FCW requesting a
return call regarding Youth A.
All of the following interviews took place on 11/13/2024 via
telephone contact along with DHHS Specialist, unless
otherwise noted.
A telephone call was made to Staff 6. He confirmed knowledge of
employee Staff 1. He denied having any concerns regarding the
staff. He also denied seeing or hearing anything from other staff
or other youth regarding Staff 1 that would create some concern.
Lastly, he denied hearing Staff 1 talk or engage with youth in an
inappropriate or sexual nature.
A telephone call was made to Staff 7. He confirmed knowledge of
Staff 1. He denied any concerns regarding the staff and denied
seeing or hearing him be inappropriate with youth. He admitted
that during the internal investigation he expressed concerns but
confirmed that the concerns were based on his “personal opinion
and judgement” of Staff 1. He confirmed that he has never
witnessed any inappropriate behavior by Staff 1. Staff 7 further
advised that he has heard Youth A say different things about this
3

situation and change her story and offer different reasons every
time of why she is not comfortable with Staff 1. He ended by
stating that he really doesn’t believe her.
A telephone interview was completed with Staff 3. She denied
witnessing Staff 1 be inappropriate with Youth A or any other
youth. She also denied hearing Staff 1 speak to Youth A or other
youth in an inappropriate manner. She confirmed that she had
completed an incident report involving Youth A and Staff 1, but
that it only involved the actions of Youth A. Youth A has
expressed concerns regarding Staff 1, but did not provide
specifics or further explanation to Staff 3.
A telephone interview was completed with Staff 4. She confirmed
that she completed an IR involving Staff 1 and Youth A. She
stated she documented the behavior of Youth A and how she was
responding to Staff 1 without any prompting from him. She denied
any concerns with Staff 1 and his interactions with Youth A. She
reported that sometimes Youth A would be “favorable” of Staff 1
and other times she was not. She recalled an incident when
Youth A would sing a song titled “They’re Not Like Us” when Staff
1 would enter a room. She would state a specific line that would
reference a person being a pedophile. She used this example to
demonstrate how Youth A would not express direct concerns
regarding Staff 1, but just make indirect comments. She denied
seeing Staff 1 on the unit with Youth A after being reassigned to
another unit.
A telephone call was made to the Adoption Worker and
Therapist of Youth A. A voicemail message was left to return
phone call.
All of the following interviews took place on 11/14/2024 at
Whaley’s along with DHHS Specialist, unless otherwise
noted.
An in-person interview was completed with Youth B. He denied
any concerns with Staff 1. He described Youth A as “weird” and
stated she is always “on some bs”. He described Staff 1 as a
"great individual" and "great person. He reported that Staff 1 is on
leave because Youth A is saying he is a "pedophile," but denies
that this is true. He denied hearing Staff 1 speak inappropriately
to Youth A or any other youth. He denied hearing Staff 1
reference a Charlie horse when speaking with Youth A. Youth B
denied ever hearing Staff 1 talk about doing porn or talk with them
4

about any personal stuff. He further denied Staff 1 ever talked
about needing "butt" or having sex around anyone.
An in-person interview was completed with Youth C. He denied
having any concerns regarding the staff. He also denied seeing or
hearing anything from other staff or other youth regarding Staff 1
that would create some concern. He denied hearing Staff 1 talk or
engage with youth in an inappropriate or sexual nature. He stated
he never saw Staff 1 touch Youth A and noted Staff 1 rarely even
talks to Youth A. When asked about statements regarding a
Charlie horse, Youth C recalled one time that him and Staff 1 were
talking, and he got a Charlie horse and Youth A asked what a
Charlie horse was. Youth C stated that Staff 1 responded, "want
me to show you?" and everyone started laughing. Staff 1 then
began to explain to Youth A as it being similar to a cramp. Youth
C denied that Staff 1 said anything about where on Youth A’s
body he would show her, and overall Staff 1 was playing. Lastly
Youth C reported that Youth A got upset because everyone was
laughing.
An in-person interview was completed with Staff 1. He denied
ever making statements about giving Youth A a Charlie horse. He
denied any conversation ever even occurred about a Charlie
horse. He denied knowledge of another youth having this
discussion with Youth A. He further denied talking about doing
porn to or around any of the youth at the agency. He denied
having any conversations with youth about “needing butt”, but
stated youth at the agency have said that they “need butt”. He
stated he redirects this type of conversation. He denied recalling
which youth have said it and stated he just knows the youth in the
facility say some outlandish things especially with it being mostly
boys on the unit.
Staff 1 reported on one occasion he did transport Youth A alone in
his personal vehicle. Review of agency policy does not prohibit
this. He reported Youth A sat in the passenger seat up front and
denied they had any conversation. He specifically recalls getting
a call on his air pod about a pending home purchase and engaged
in that call. Staff 1 reported he was not around Youth A much
because she would be at school during first shift. He recalled on
one other time that he was alone with Youth A when he was
asked to take her to the gym and she just roller skated around
with her headphones on. When asked about his relationship with
Youth A, he responded that it is up and down. He stated, “she
hates me and then she likes me and then she hates me again.”
Staff 1 confirmed that he was placed on a safety plan and advised
5

not to be around Youth A. He was assigned to another facility to
work. He stated it was later clarified for him not to be in the unit at
all when Youth A would be. Staff 1 stated he would be in the unit
on Saturday morning until about 8:30 am when the youth would
wake up. He stated this was just routine behavior for him. He
stated he would just talk with staff and then leave. On about two
occasions he was in the unit he stated he saw Youth A, but did not
say anything to her and just walked out when he saw her. Staff 1
was advised to be mindful of safety plan and how important it is to
follow it to ensure Youth A can feel safe and comfortable and also
for his safety against any additional allegations.
An in-person interview was completed with Youth D and Youth E.
They both confirmed knowledge of employee Staff 1. They denied
having any concerns regarding the staff. They also denied seeing
or hearing anything from other staff or other youth regarding Staff
1 that would create some concern. Lastly, they both denied
hearing Staff 1 talk or engage with youth in an inappropriate or
sexual nature.
All of the following interviews took place on 11/19/2024 via
telephone along with DHHS Specialist, unless otherwise
noted.
A telephone interview was completed with Staff 5. She denied
having any concerns regarding the staff. She also denied seeing
or hearing anything from other staff or other youth regarding Staff
1 that would create concern. She also denied hearing Staff 1 talk
or engage with youth in an inappropriate or sexual nature. She
did confirm that Youth A once told her that Staff 1 makes her feel
uncomfortable. She requested assistance from Staff 5 and stated
that she did not want Staff 1 to help her because he rubs her the
wrong way. When asked, Youth A did not provide further details.
She claimed to have recordings on her MP3 player, but when she
showed it to Staff 5 like she was going to play it, she just started
laughing and never played anything. Staff 5 reported that a
couple days later, Youth A came into the unit from outside trying

5 stated that when she asked Youth A why she would say that,
she did not provide any further details.
A telephone call was completed with Therapist. She reported she
began therapy with Youth A the week of 10/28, but that Youth A
refused two weeks of sessions. Youth A was also refusing therapy
with the prior therapist. Two sessions have been completed with
Youth A on 11/7 and 11/14 with the focus being on building
6

rapport. Therapist stated that from a therapeutic lens, the biggest
thing she has noticed with Youth A is that she is pretty
institutionalized, and she believes she self-sabotages a lot. When
seeing Youth A last week she shared about her experience in
court when she spoke about Staff 1 and stated it made her
uncomfortable. She shared that she did not like some comments
Staff 1 made to her, but did not go into detail. Therapist denied
that Youth A expressed any other concerns regarding Staff 1 or
any other staff. Youth A ended by saying that she did not want to
talk about it again.
A telephone call was made to Complainant and voicemail
message left requesting a return call.
All of the following interviews took place on 11/20/2024 via
telephone along with DHHS Specialist, unless otherwise
noted.
A telephone call was completed with Staff 9. He confirmed that
Youth A brought up concerns to him about Staff 1. He reported
she was crying, expressed some concerns, and he completed an
incident report. He denied knowing what led up to her crying. She
did state that Staff 1 was saying inappropriate things to her and
asked if she ever had a Charlie horse on her leg and that made
her feel uncomfortable. Youth A also stated Staff 1 was the one to
open the door for her in the morning and she said she didn't like it.
Youth A also stated Staff 1 would say “look down” when he
opened the door. Staff 9 did not know what that statement meant
and advised that Youth A did not provide further details. Staff 9
reports he advised his supervisor and Staff 1 was assigned to
another unit. He denied having knowledge of Staff 1 returning to
the unit of Youth A at all.
A telephone call was completed with Staff 8. She confirmed that
Youth A brought concerns up to her about Staff 1. She stated
Youth A told her he said some things that made her
uncomfortable; something about a leg cramp. Staff 8 does not
recall exactly what was said but recalls Youth A said it made her
feel uncomfortable. She does not recall Youth A stating anything
else that was “super alarming”. Staff 8 stated a safety plan was
created that day and Staff 1 was swapped to another unit. Staff 8
denied knowledge that Staff 1 continued to work with Youth A and
is not aware of any times that he returned to the unit. She denied
having any concerns regarding the staff. She also denied seeing
or hearing anything from other staff or other youth regarding Staff
7

1 that would create some concern. She also denied hearing Staff
1 talk or engage with youth in an inappropriate or sexual nature.
On 11/20/2024 a telephone call was made to FCW. No concerns
regarding Whaley and the care of Youth A were noted.
On 11/22/2024 the DHHS Dispo conference was held via Teams.
DHHS specialist, Area Manager, Adoption Worker and RCTAU
Analyst were present. The investigation details were discussed
and preliminary findings of the licensing investigation were
provided. DHHS advised that final results of their investigation
would be provided upon completion. At the writing of this report it
was noted that no findings were made by DHHS.
Documents Reviewed (Allegation 1):
Staff 1 Employee HR file: 12/19/2023 – Written warning for
failing to review and sign Population Book. 03/20/2024 –
Suspension for having a Vape on site that a youth at the agency
was able to obtain.
Incident Reports:
Dated 10/6/24: This report was completed by Staff 4. It reads:

Dated 10/6/24: This report was completed by Staff 4. It reads:
"Youth A walked onto the living unit and said, ‘why the fuck you

Dated 10/6/24: This report was completed by Staff 5 and reads:
"Youth A came from outside into the unit attacking Staff 1. This

8

Staff 1. Staff asked Youth A to stop throwing items. Youth A then
pushed the chair against Staff 1 stating ‘you know what you did to

staff and youth from the area."
Professional Boundaries and Personal Involvement with
Children policy: This policy indicates, “due to the trauma history
of the youth placed at WCC and the nature of some of the
behaviors exhibited by the children in our care, it is crucial that all
staff maintain professional boundaries and refrain from
inappropriate and unprofessional interactions with the children
placed at the Center.” Prohibited interactions and activities are
outlined as well as what is expected. There is no time that a staff
should be using profane language, exhibiting inappropriate
behaviors, or discussing adult subject matter in the presence of
the children.
Interviews (Allegation 2):
On 10/30/2024 an in-person interview was completed at Mott
Residence with Compliance Supervisor. She confirmed that
during her interview of both Youth A and Staff 1 it was reported
that McDonalds was purchased by Staff 1 for Youth A and a
school friend when he picked her up from school. It was also
confirmed that staff did not obtain prior approval to transport youth
to McDonalds.
On 10/30/2024 an in-person interview was completed at Mott
Residence with Youth A. She reported when Staff 1 picked her
up from school he purchased her and her friend from school some
food from McDonalds. Youth A advised that she asked Staff 1 to
purchase the food for her and her friend. Youth A further
confirmed that she rode in the car with Staff 1 to McDonalds.
On 11/14/2024 an in-person interview was completed with Staff 1.
He reported that once when he picked up Youth A from school, he
drove Youth A to McDonalds where he purchased food for both
Youth A and her friend at school. Staff 1 also confirmed that he
has purchased McDonalds for other youth at the facility. He
stated that he does not believe that it is a violation of policy, he
just thinks that they cannot have caffeine.
On 11/14/2024 and in-person interview was completed with
Director. She advised that purchasing food for youth has to be
approved and there are a lot of guidelines. She admitted that all
staff purchase food for the kids, but they are not to bring it around
9

the other kids if everyone isn’t getting some. She confirmed that
staff does not always obtain permission in advance.
On 01/12/2024 an email correspondence was received from
Director. She confirmed that she did not provide accurate
information regarding staff requiring permission prior to
purchasing food for youth. She confirmed that the agency does
not have such policy.
Documents (Allegation 2):
Whaley’s Off- Ground Activity Procedures: All Whaley staff
must contact a manager on duty to obtain approval to take a child
off campus and sign the child out. Once the child returns to the
milieu from the activity, Whaley staff officials must sign the child
back in with management.
Analysis Regarding Allegation #1: at the conclusion of the investigation
there was not sufficient evidence to support non-compliance of the
licensing rule. The interview responses from both staff and youth
in the program were not consistent and failed to provide
convincing evidence that supports and assessment of non-
compliance with the licensing rule.
Regarding Allegation #2: At the conclusion of the investigation
there was sufficient evidence to assess non-compliance with the
licensing rule. After interviews of youth and staff it was indicated
that the agency staff took the youth to an unauthorized off campus
location (McDonalds) without agency permission.
Technical Assistance
The purchase of food items by staff for youth without agency
approval needs to be addressed in policy.
Conclusion Repeat Violation Established

Rule Code Compliance with child protection law; development of plan
Title required.
10

Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4131
Section (1) The licensee shall develop and implement a written plan to
Description assure compliance with the child protection law, 1975 PA 238,
MCL 722.621 to 722.638.
Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation Agency staff failed to call in a suspicion of child abuse or neglect
to centralized intake.
Investigation Interviews:
On 11/14/2024 an in-person interview was completed with
Director at Whaley. DHHS specialist was also present. She
confirmed that the agency completed an internal investigation
regarding the allegations involving Youth A and Staff 1. After the
conclusion of the internal investigation the agency assessed no
areas of concern. Director advised that the agency did not make
a referral to centralized intake for suspected abuse and/or neglect.
Director was advised that agency should always contact
centralized intake with concerns of suspected abuse and/or
neglect as documented in the agency policy. She was also
advised of the concerns associated with the agency completing an
internal investigation prior to DCWL, DHHS, or Law Enforcement
involvement.
Documentation Review:
Whaley Internal Investigation Report: Date of Complaint was
indicated as 9/28/24 - 9/29/24. Complaint was received on
10/1/2024 and internal agency investigation was completed by
Compliance Supervisor and Staff 3. Conclusion (Fact Finding
based on all interviews/evidence): After interviewing Youth A,
other youth and staff relevant to this complaint, it was determined
by Compliance Supervisor Youth A’s accusations have no current
evidence to support whether they are true or not. Further
investigation is needed to provide a resolution to this complaint. A
safety plan was immediately put in place when this complaint was
received for Youth A and Staff 1. Staff 1 was moved permanently
to Optimist (boys group home) and was told he is not to have any
contact with Youth A. Compliance Recommendations (To be
Completed by Compliance Supervisor): That safety plan for Staff 1
and Youth A remain in place until further notice. Staff 1 should
have no contact with Youth A and Staff 1 should be coached
regarding appropriate boundaries with youth residing at Whaley.
11

Report and recommendations provided to management and other
administration on 10/24/2024.
Agency Mandated Reporting Policy - (WCC Residential Policies
& Procedures Section II, Part H). The policy indicates that as
regulated childcare providers, Whaley staff are mandated
reporters in accordance with Section 722 of the Child Protection
Law. In the event a child reports or you become aware of any
possible abuse or neglect, you must report to DHHS- Children’s
Protective Services Centralized Intake by calling 1-855-444-3911
within 24 hours of receiving the information.
Child Complaint Policy - (WCC Residential Policies &
Procedures Section VII, Part F). The policy indicates that any
staff member who initially receives a complaint from a child can
either call in to the child abuse hotline on their own or notify their
Residential Manager before the end of the current shift. Per Public
Law, staff can call the complaint on their own but are encouraged
to utilize Residential Management for support. Staff members that
need to file a complaint after hours should contact CRT. Once the
reporting staff member files the complaint then he/she should get
the log number and enter that number on the DHHS-3200 Form.
Analysis At the conclusion of the investigation, the agency was found to be
in non-compliance with licensing rule 4131. Interviews of staff and
administrators confirmed that the agency failed to make a report of
suspected abuse or neglect to the State of Michigan centralized
intake line.
Technical Assistance:
The agency’s reporting policy and child complaint policy need to
be updated so they are in line with the Child Protection Law. The
policy should indicate staff are to contact central intake
immediately rather than 24 hours and the staff who becomes
aware of the alleged abuse must report the abuse and not wait for
a manager to be notified.
Conclusion Violation Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. A corrective action plan is required.
